symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) - unlikely given normal PFTs but should be considered
Multiple chemical sensitivity (MCS) - Note: This is a controversial diagnosis with limited scientific evidence.
Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) (Crohns disease or ulcerative colitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
Vasovagal syncope (neurocardiogenic syncope) with unrelated gastrointestinal and dermatological symptoms
Postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS) with unrelated gastrointestinal and dermatological symptoms
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) - Crohns Disease or Ulcerative Colitis
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohns disease, ulcerative colitis)
justification: Life-threatening allergic reaction that can cause flushing, angioedema, abdominal cramps, and in rare cases, incontinence due to loss of bladder control.}, {diagnosis: Mastocytosis
justification: Rare disorder causing mast cell accumulation, leading to flushing, angioedema, abdominal cramps, and in some cases, incontinence.}, {diagnosis: Carcinoid syndrome
justification: Tumors release hormones causing flushing, abdominal cramps, and diarrhea, which may be mistaken for incontinence.}, {diagnosis: Hereditary angioedema
justification: Genetic condition causing recurrent angioedema, potentially leading to abdominal pain and, rarely, incontinence due to swelling.}, {diagnosis: Food poisoning (certain types)
justification: Severe food poisoning can cause flushing, abdominal cramps, and potentially incontinence due to vomiting and diarrhea.}, {diagnosis: Medication side effects
justification: Certain medications can cause flushing, angioedema, abdominal cramps, and urinary incontinence as side effects.}, {diagnosis: Panic disorder (severe)
justification: Extreme anxiety can cause flushing, abdominal cramps, and in some cases, incontinence.}, {diagnosis: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)

justification: Conditions like Crohns disease and ulcerative colitis can cause abdominal cramps, diarrhea (potentially mistaken for incontinence), and occasionally flushing.}, {diagnosis: Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)

justification: Infection affecting female reproductive organs causing abdominal cramps, and potentially urinary incontinence in severe cases.}, {diagnosis: Urinary tract infection (UTI) with complications
justification: While UTIs typically cause painful urination, complications can lead to abdominal pain, and occasionally incontinence.}
